speaker: All
text_entry: SCENE IV. The same. A room in the palace.

speaker: All
text_entry: Enter MARK ANTONY and CLEOPATRA, CHARMIAN, and others attending

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Eros! mine armour, Eros!

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Sleep a little.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: No, my chuck. Eros, come; mine armour, Eros!

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Enter EROS with armour

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Come good fellow, put mine iron on:

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: If fortune be not ours to-day, it is

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Because we brave her: come.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Nay, I'll help too.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: What's this for?

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Ah, let be, let be! thou art

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: The armourer of my heart: false, false; this, this.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Sooth, la, I'll help: thus it must be.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Well, well;

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: We shall thrive now. Seest thou, my good fellow?

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Go put on thy defences.

speaker: EROS
text_entry: Briefly, sir.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Is not this buckled well?

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Rarely, rarely:

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: He that unbuckles this, till we do please

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: To daff't for our repose, shall hear a storm.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Thou fumblest, Eros; and my queen's a squire

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: More tight at this than thou: dispatch. O love,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: That thou couldst see my wars to-day, and knew'st

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: The royal occupation! thou shouldst see

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: A workman in't.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Enter an armed Soldier

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Good morrow to thee; welcome:

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Thou look'st like him that knows a warlike charge:

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: To business that we love we rise betime,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: And go to't with delight.

speaker: Soldier
text_entry: A thousand, sir,

speaker: Soldier
text_entry: Early though't be, have on their riveted trim,

speaker: Soldier
text_entry: And at the port expect you.

speaker: Soldier
text_entry: Shout. Trumpets flourish

speaker: Soldier
text_entry: Enter Captains and Soldiers

speaker: Captain
text_entry: The morn is fair. Good morrow, general.

speaker: All
text_entry: Good morrow, general.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: 'Tis well blown, lads:

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: This morning, like the spirit of a youth

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: That means to be of note, begins betimes.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: So, so; come, give me that: this way; well said.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Fare thee well, dame, whate'er becomes of me:

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: This is a soldier's kiss: rebukeable

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Kisses her

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: And worthy shameful cheque it were, to stand

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: On more mechanic compliment; I'll leave thee

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Now, like a man of steel. You that will fight,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Follow me close; I'll bring you to't. Adieu.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Exeunt MARK ANTONY, EROS, Captains, and Soldiers

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: Please you, retire to your chamber.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Lead me.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: He goes forth gallantly. That he and Caesar might

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Determine this great war in single fight!

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Then Antony,--but now--Well, on.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Exeunt
